awd_titl_txt: Divergent Catalysis for Metal Carbene Reactions
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract

In this project funded by the Chemical Synthesis program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Michael Doyle of the University of Texas at San Antonio is investigating catalytically generated metal carbenes as synthetic tools for the construction of complex organic compounds.  This research provides fundamental advances in catalysis for metal carbene formation and reactions and offers research opportunities for the education of students who are preparing for careers in the chemical sciences.  The research program includes initiatives to increase diversity, particularly through greater participation of Hispanic and African American students, and undergraduate participation in research.  Efforts are undertaken to cultivate an international consortia to investigate critical unsolved problems in chemical catalysis for metal carbene generation and reactions.  

Catalytic processes using carbene precursors that operate with stereocontrol and diversity in product formation are under investigation. Professor Doyle is pursuing the development of donor-acceptor cyclopropenes as effective carbene precursors. The research provides catalysts with divergent reactivities and that improve the stereoselectivity in intramolecular metal carbene additions. The research broadens the scope and expands the versatility of chemical transformations that occur through metal carbene intermediates.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Our program focused on the design and development of new selective catalytic metal carbene transformations with emphasis on the development of catalyst-directed divergent outcomes, determination of the catalytic feasibility for the uses of donor-acceptor cyclopropenes as metal carbene sources, and the discovery of new catalytic highly stereoselective reactions of structurally complex diazo compounds.

The transition metal catalyzed vinylcarbene approach to cycloaddition has been developed for highly chemoselective, regioselective, and stereoselective [3+n]-cycloaddition reactions. In these chemical processes, silyl-protected 3-enol-2-diazo compounds supply three carbon atoms to the cyclic structure, and a second entity provide n atoms (C, N, and/or O) to the [3+n]-cycloaddition structure. The diazo compound is selected from diazoacetates, diazoamides, diazoketones, and diazosulfones with similar capabilities to undergo cycloaddition reactions, in reactions catalyzed by transition metal compounds that convert the diazo compound into a reactive metal carbene. [3+3]-, [3+2]-, and even a [3+1]-cycloaddition reaction have been reported using dipolar metallo-vinylcarbenes generated from silyl-protected enoldiazo compounds, generally in high yields with low catalyst loadings. The normally high reactivity of the metallo-vinylcarbene is moderated by intramolecular collapse to donor-acceptor cyclopropenes that can reform the metallo-vinylcarbene and are, because of this, the resting state for the metallo-vinylcarbenes. These cycloaddition reactions involve initial nucleophilic attachment to the electrophilic vinylogous position of the metallo-vinylcarbene followed by electrophilic addition to the original carbenic center with displacement of the catalyst.  Those systems that have been examined suggest a broad applicability of this methodology. During the course of this grant period we have demonstrated the use of copper(I) catalysis to supplant the reliance of this methodology on the more expensive dirhodium(II) catalysts to achieve high yields and selectivities.

In a parallel goal of our research into metal carbene chemistry we sought to access structurally different compounds from the same reactant(s) with different transition metal catalysts. We approached this challenge in two directions. One was been to utilize polyfunctional diazocarbonyl compounds that undergo different reaction pathways to produce unique products with different catalysts, and with this approach we introduced gold catalysis in reactions of propargyl diazoesters which formed products that were different from those produced with dirhodium or copper catalysts. The second approach was to produce different chemical intermediates whose combination results in different products, dependent on the calalyst that was used. Diazocarbonyl compounds provided unique opportunities to develop these approaches because they form metal carbene intermediates having different reactivities and selectivities, and they can be linked intermolecularly or intramolecularly to form other reactive intermediates. These approaches have been widely adopted in other metal carbene transformations.


Last Modified: 07/30/2019
Modified by: Michael P Doyle
